ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: I met once a week with the senior essay group on Zoom, and once a week socially-distanced on my advisor's front porch since she happened to live a block away from me.
We worked independently for the most part. Our seminar meetings were supplementary to our overarching projects

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Writing a thesis presents an opportunity to do independent research and work one on one with faculty in a specialized field in way in a unique way. It's a definitely the most intellectually stimulating and challenging thing I've done at Yale, but also by far the most rewarding.
The senior essay was an enormous opportunity for me to improve my writing skills, on every scale.
how to write a big academic paper

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really liked the way the course was structured-- the best part being a dedicated TA to run a weekly colloquium for the writers, virtual writing retreats, etc.

What makes this course so strong is the amazing amount of feedback and support from professors and mentors. I was so grateful for all their generosity. The only thing that could have been improved slightly is that I might have appreciated slightly more clarity early-on about deadlines, formats, etc.

The writing retreats were REALLY useful. The only real weakness was an overall lack of clarity on requirements and deadlines. We didn't know the length requirement for our projects until several weeks into the term and the final deadline wasn't clarified for quite a while. A more concrete syllabus with requirements and deadlines would be very useful

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The Zoom workshops worked beautifully, especially when we just worked while on the same call. It gave some much-needed accountability. I think Zoom worked well for this course mostly because the number of students was so small.
the virtual writing retreats were really useful

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you have a topic you're passionate about, relevant faculty that you'd like to work with on a weekly basis, and are willing to put in the effort, I would absolutely recommend this class.

Absolutely! Writing a senior essay is a lot of work and it isn't for everyone, but if you want an opportunity to work on your academic writing with enormous amounts of professorial support and feedback, there's no better way to do it. This course gave me a taste of what it's like to really have ownership over a large project of my own, and taught me a lot about my writing and thinking habits. If you're thinking about graduate school, you should 100% do this. If you're not, it's still a really satisfying way to put a capstone on your English major.
If you are a senior english major!
